alert.note: Alert for Ottawa (Michigan) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 09 at 9:04PM EDT until April 13 at 11:00PM EDT by NWS Grand Rapids
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Michigan... Grand River at Robinson Township affecting Ottawa County. Grand River at Grand Rapids affecting Kent County. Grand River at Lowell affecting Kent County. Grand River near Comstock Park affecting Kent County. ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Michigan... Maple River at Maple Rapids affecting Clinton County. Thornapple River Near Caledonia affecting Kent County. Thornapple River Above Hastings affecting Barry County. For the Grand River...including Jackson, Eaton Rapids - USGS, Eaton Rapids, Dimondale, Lansing, Grand Ledge, Portland, Ionia, Lowell, Ada, Comstock Park, Grand Rapids, Eastmanville, Robinson Township... Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Maple River...including Maple Rapids...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Thornapple River...including Hastings, Caledonia...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE THURSDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Grand River at Robinson Township. * WHEN...Until late Thursday evening. * IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Vanlopik Road is 2 to 3 feet under water. Moderate flooding of several homes on the east end of Vanlopik subdivision occurs. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 PM EDT Sunday the stage was 15.1 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:45 PM EDT Sunday was 15.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 15.6 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage late Wednesday evening. - Flood stage is 13.3 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 15.6 feet on 03/28/1997. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/grr.
